Comments_List: I learned about the background knowledge of computational visions.

This was a good survey of a number of computational vision techniques/important algorithms -- gradient ascent, backpropagation, machine learning, etc. Overall, a nice course to apply computer science knowledge.
Mathematics is beautiful.
fundemental knowledge on computer vision
computer vision
Biological perception, edge detection, image processing.
Knowledge about computer vision like convolution, edge detection, visual cortex ,etc. This course teaches us how to analyze real life problems .
computer vision. Math. matlab
Basic concepts about computer vision and learn to implement the algorithms by myself.
we spent like 70% in biology and math background, and 30% in CV algorithms.
Some CV related ML algorithms, basic neuroscience
Computer vision, neural networks, biological perception
Rudimentary Knowledge about our vision systems.
The lecture notes of this course is kind of poorly organized.

It covered a lot of different concepts, and the student's level of interest really dictates how much they will learn from the class. That means that a motivated student can walk away with a fairly robust understanding of a number of computational vision techniques. cons -- it was a little scattered, especially since it covered so many topics, and the tests were not very representative of the core technical course material. 

Tests could be adjusted to be more representative of lecture. Currently they're fairly easy, but not what you would study from the online notes or lecture notes.

One strength would be that Prof. Zucker's lecture is very engaging (he seems to have a lot of jokes prepared for the subject matter of each lecture). Another strength is that the homework is well-designed, and really helps the learning process. 

One weakness would be that Prof. Zucker's handwriting on the blackboard is sometimes hard to read. Although lecture notes are uploaded in the form of chapters from the textbook, I hope concise version of printed notes can be provided. That would make it easier to study for exams.
Very good course
interesting course. notes could be more organized

If the lecture notes could be made easier for non-bio students to understand it would be much better; or the homework assignments could be made harder so that we can gain deeper understanding of the material.

The professor is humorous. 
I think the lecture notes are not concise enough

Strengths: homework is well-designed and Professor Zucker is very humorous
Weaknesses: lecture nodes could be improved more.
The course is certainly a great introductory course for CV. the only weakness, in my opinion, is that the assignments are required to be done in matlab, and i don't like matlab,
The lecture handouts can be condensed, and lectures are a bit hard to follow; homework and TA are really helpful
Clear lectures accompanied by clear lecture notes
Strength: a lot of useful and interesting materials covered.
I would recommend this course to students who want to learn more about the computational models about animal visions.
Yes, it's a great course for a CS or BME student to branch out and learn a bit more about each field. Prof Zucker is engaging, lively, and very knowledgeable.

I would definitely recommend because this course introduces me to a whole new wonderful area of computer science (in a beautifully presented way). Although the lectures can be hard to follow sometimes since I have not done anything related to computer vision before, the lectures are well-structured and homework sets are well-designed. As a result, the learning process is quite pleasant. And besides all that, the computer vision area is wonderful in that you can see how beautiful mathematics is.
Yes, it is very interesting and you will learn a lot about CV
yes, it is interesting

Yes. The course teaches very interesting topics in computational vision in biology. The teaching staff teach the course with great enthusiasm, and provide high quality feedback. The topics being taught in this course are different from what we usually learn from all other courses, but yet related and useful. You feel highly engaged and motivated to learn in this course.
Of course. Professor Zucker is great!
Yes. Its necessary for computer vision. And it combines biology and computer vision.
Sure. It provides a clear structure and introduction for students who are interested in computer vision.
Neutral
Yes. Great theoretical understanding of computer vision, as well as applicational aspects and up-to-date knowledge of neural networks
Yes, very well organized lectures and helpful homeworks.
